comments.text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:7.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/7.0.1
Build ID: 20110928134238

Steps to reproduce:

Browsing the internet with few tabs open


Actual results:

Firefox freezes. No new tabs can be opened. No old tabs can be viewed and the browser is unresponsive. 
Created DMP file. Attaching it here.

comments.text:
yes - the crash is forced crash. The lockup happens often (since I upgraded to 7.0.1 I believe). When I get it again I will create another forced crash.

You cannot attach such crash files here because Mozilla limits the size of the attachments. Or so it seemed.

comments.author: ceco@commtouch.com
comments.text:
It just happened today. As I was preparing to create forced DUMP, (which I did) it appears that Adobe Flash crashed it. After a while - Mozilla recovered. I can provide the dump file although it might be a plugin causing the misbehavior. The current version of the Adobe Flash as reported in the Add-ons Manager is: 10.1.1.33 and "Check to see if your plugins are up to date" states my plugins are up-to-date.
Shokwave I have is reported to be: 10.3.183.10 - also up-to-date.
comments.raw_text:
It just happened today. As I was preparing to create forced DUMP, (which I did) it appears that Adobe Flash crashed it. After a while - Mozilla recovered. I can provide the dump file although it might be a plugin causing the misbehavior. The current version of the Adobe Flash as reported in the Add-ons Manager is: 10.1.1.33 and "Check to see if your plugins are up to date" states my plugins are up-to-date.
Shokwave I have is reported to be: 10.3.183.10 - also up-to-date.

You have some confusion there.
The newest Flash plugin is 11.0.1.152. The version 10.3.183.10 is the previous version (or the newest in the 10.3 series, if you wish to stay there).
I don't know about Shockwave. Maybe you just swapped the names.
Firefox should recover when the flash plugin dies or hangs. But it needs some time (like a minute) until it decides the plugin is hung.
comments.text:
You have some confusion there.
The newest Flash plugin is 11.0.1.152. The version 10.3.183.10 is the previous version (or the newest in the 10.3 series, if you wish to stay there).
I don't know about Shockwave. Maybe you just swapped the names.
Firefox should recover when the flash plugin dies or hangs. But it needs some time (like a minute) until it decides the plugin is hung.

comments.author: ceco@commtouch.com
comments.creator: ceco@commtouch.com

comments.text: Yes, there is Adobe Acrobat 10.1.1.33, which you called Adobe Flash. Then there is Shockwave Flash, which you called just Shockwave. There exists a Shockwave player, that is not Flash, but a different plugin (technology). So your comment was a bit messy. But now it is clear. It seems the plugin check page does not offer Flash 11.0.1.152 yet. (But on http://get.adobe.com/flashplayer/ you'll see it.) Could you disable the flash plugin for several days to see if it causes the problem?
comments.raw_text: Yes, there is Adobe Acrobat 10.1.1.33, which you called Adobe Flash. Then there is Shockwave Flash, which you called just Shockwave. There exists a Shockwave player, that is not Flash, but a different plugin (technology). So your comment was a bit messy. But now it is clear. It seems the plugin check page does not offer Flash 11.0.1.152 yet. (But on http://get.adobe.com/flashplayer/ you'll see it.) Could you disable the flash plugin for several days to see if it causes the problem?

comments.raw_text: Happened again this morning. Waited a bit longer and Firefox recovered. The crash is in Adobe Flash player. This - with the updated Flash Player. I sent the report. This might in fact be Adobe Flash Player issue. Possibly happens on www.endgadget.com (I usually leave it overnight on that site).
comments.text: Happened again this morning. Waited a bit longer and Firefox recovered. The crash is in Adobe Flash player. This - with the updated Flash Player. I sent the report. This might in fact be Adobe Flash Player issue. Possibly happens on www.endgadget.com (I usually leave it overnight on that site).

comments.author: ceco@commtouch.com

comments.creator: acelists@atlas.sk
comments.author: acelists@atlas.sk
comments.text:
Where did you sent a report? To Adobe?
How long did you need to wait for Firefox to recover? But it is good that it did.
You can got to about:config and see to what value the preference "dom.ipc.plugins.timeoutSecs" is set.
So you could continue to use it just fine after that? Can you try to leave any other browser on that page, what happens there?
comments.raw_text:
Where did you sent a report? To Adobe?
How long did you need to wait for Firefox to recover? But it is good that it did.
You can got to about:config and see to what value the preference "dom.ipc.plugins.timeoutSecs" is set.
So you could continue to use it just fine after that? Can you try to leave any other browser on that page, what happens there?

Most likely Adobe. When the crash occurs there's "send report" link and "restart" link. 
I just clicked the "Send Report Link" that is displayed when the crash occurred. 
The other opened tabs (theregister.co.uk) also had the plugin crashed.
I think I had to wait over 30 seconds (not sure, didn't measure it - this is how it felt).
dom.ipc.plugins.timeoutSecs = 45  (comes by default, have not altered it)
Firefox is usable after the crash. Even the Adobe Flash is usable after the restart of Flash (w/o the need to close Firefox).
I have not yet tried other browser on that page. I will leave one overnight. The tabs opened were:

cnbc.com
endgadget.com
theregister.co.uk
